revealed_symptoms.pruritus: It’s super itchy sometimes, or feels kind of tingly, like a weird sensation under my skin.
revealed_symptoms.erythema: The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something.
revealed_symptoms.spontaneous bleeding: Sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.
revealed_symptoms.shiny or waxy bump: It looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.

hidden_symptoms.telangiectasia: There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before.
hidden_symptoms.evolving: This thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
hidden_symptoms.induration: It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there.
hidden_symptoms.asymmetry: One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven.
hidden_symptoms.border irregularity: The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles.
hidden_symptoms.satellite lesions: There are these little dots or spots popping up near the main one, like it’s spreading.
hidden_symptoms.rapid growth: I swear this mole or bump got bigger really fast, like in just a few weeks.
hidden_symptoms.hyperkeratosis: There's this rough, flaky spot that won’t go away, and sometimes it peels.

patient_history.content: Hi, I'll be your doctor today. What brings you in?

Well, lately, I've noticed this spot on my skin that's been really itchy, like a weird sensation under my skin, and it's sometimes red and puffy. Also, it's started bleeding on its own sometimes, even if I don't touch it. It also looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.

Thank you for providing that information. To better understand what's happening, could you tell me how big the spot is, like, roughly in inches or centimeters? Also, where on your body is this spot located?
I'm not sure exactly how big it is, but maybe like the size of a dime? It's on my skin.

Thanks. To help me understand this better, could you describe the shape of the spot? Is it round, irregular, or something else? Also, have you noticed if this spot has changed over time, like getting bigger or changing color?
The shape is a little irregular, not perfectly round. And yeah, I think it's been changing, maybe getting a little bigger or looking different than before.
Thank you. Has this spot been exposed to the sun a lot over time, or have you had a lot of sunburns in the past? Also, do you have a family history of skin cancer?
I don’t think it’s been exposed to the sun a lot, and I haven't had many sunburns. I don't know about my family history.

Thank you. Can you describe the color of the spot? Also, is the border of the spot well-defined, or does it seem to blend into the surrounding skin? Have you noticed any other symptoms, like pain or any discharge from the spot?
The skin around it looks red. The border is kinda jagged, not smooth. No pain or discharge.
Thanks. Has the texture of the spot itself changed? For instance, has it become scaly, crusty, or hard in any areas? Also, have you noticed any changes to the spot's appearance lately?
It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there. And yeah, it keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.

Based on the information you've provided, and given that the lesion is changing and has some concerning features, it is likely that you have either Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) or Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC). It is important to determine which of these diagnoses are correct. I recommend seeing a dermatologist to get this checked out further. They can examine the spot more closely and probably do a biopsy to know for sure what's going on. Would you like a referral?
Sure, that sounds like a good idea.
